bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jessie Daniel Ames, March 24, 1942

div1.p: Hench appreciates the list of documents Jessie Ames sent to him. He poses specific questions about her husband's role in the yellow fever experiments and inquires about old fever charts and carbon copies of various letters.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jessie Daniel Ames, March 24, 1942
div1.opener:
March 24, 1942
Mrs. Jessie D. Ames
700 Standard Building
Atlanta, Georgia
My dear Mrs. Ames:
div1.p:
I certainly do appreciate your sending me the most interesting collection
of letters and records about your husband. I am studying them with great interest
and am making copies of some of the items, assuming that you are willing for me to
have them so that I may know as much as I can about your husband's medical work in
Cuba and later. Will you permit me to ask you a few specific questions?

list.item:
1. In the Senate Document 61 (compilation of papers on yellow fever by
Reed et al) it says that your husband was in charge of Camp Lazear. When I was in
Havana I asked Mr. Moran about this and he said he could not recall having seen your
husband at Camp Lazear at any time during the days he (Moran) was there. It was
Moran's impression that Dr. Ames stayed at Camp Columbia and of course Moran's memory
may have played him false and certainly Moran was not trying to minimize Dr. Ames'
service. He spoke most highly of them and indicated the great importance of Dr. Ames'
successful services to all the soldiers with experimental yellow fever. When in
Chicago recently I asked Mr. Lambert about this. He readily recalled Dr. Ames' presence
at Camp Lazear. Can you give me any details to amplify the above? Do you recall any
incidents, etc. which Dr. Ames told you about his visits to Camp Lazear? Did he sleep
at Camp Lazear or at Columbia Barracks while Camp Lazear was open, etc.? I am so
anxious to get a complete and accurate picture of his services. I note that Dr. Reed
(in his letter of Mar. 11, 1901) mentions Dr. Ames' “administrative work of the camp.”

2. Some of my correspondents have asked me whether Dr. Ames truly had yellow
fever in Cuba. I am delighted to have proof thereof in the form of his “yellow fever
immunity card” which I shall photostat.

3. In Dr. Reed's letter (March 11, 1901) and somewhere else I can't at the
moment recall, I have noted that Dr. Ames made a map of the Quemados epidemic of yellow
fever--apparently he indicated on a map of the town which houses or blocks were infected
with yellow fever. Do you have any idea where that map is? I have hunted for it in
the National Archives (Washington) among the mass of data pretaining to yellow fever
in Cuba, Reed, etc. etc. Do you happen to have a copy of it in your possession? I am
most anxious to trace it. The Reed family do not have it. In Dr. Reed's letter of
March 26, 1901 he acknowledges receipt of the map and “the accompanying histories of
the cases of early and late yellow fever.” Do you have any idea where these case
histories are? I can't locate them in Washington.

4. Who is the Dr. James referred to in Reed's letter of Mar. 26, 1901? Is
it perchance Dr. James Carroll? I suspect not.

5. In Reed's letter of Dec. 21, 1901 he says, “Concerning the charts for
your book ----etc. I hope you will put your experiences in permanent form ----.” Did
Dr. Ames ever write a book or articles about his yellow fever work?

6. Do you have any copies of Dr. Ames' photograph either of 1899-1901
or of 1902? I can of course have those in your book copied but they aren't any too
clear--the one is somewhat soiled, the other somewhat faded. If you have one I'd like
very much to have it not only that I may reproduce it in my book but that I may place one
permanently in the little medical museum I hope to see erected some day at Camp Lazear.

7. I will copy the group photo with Dr. Ames in the center and show it to
Lambert, Moran, Truby, Kean and others to see if they can identify the place and the
men therein. I do not recognize any of the men as being those in the yellow fever
experiments although I have seen several photos of those men. I assume there is no
notation on the back of the photo.

8. In Dr. Ames' letter to the Surgeon-General dated Dec. 30, 1901 he requests
charts and clinical records of yellow fever cases treated by him in Cuba. Did he ever
receive these charts? I wonder where they are? We could find practically none of
them in Washington.

9. In Dr. Ames' letter October 10, 1905 to the Surgeon General he mentions
"a book published by the Medical Dept.--“History of Yellow Fever at Military Posts.”
I have not run across such a book. Do you know it? Did Dr. Ames obtain a copy?

10. Could you send me a copy of your “Record--Roger Post Ames, M.D., in Yellow
Fever Experimentation, etc.”? It is important for me to have such a copy and if you
have one for me it would save considerable time and expense copying it. Also do you
have a copy of the “copy” placed in your book behind this “Record” in the same trans-
parent envelope?

item.p:
11. I don't suppose you have any more carbon copies of the various letters
in enclosures XXXI and XXXII--letters from the War Dept., from Senator Sheppard and
General Smith; your interview with General Ireland, letters from Agramonte, Andrus and
Lambert. I feel very presumptuous in asking if you do have spare copies but our photo-
graphic department is swamped with work as is also my own secretary (due to spring
medical meetings) and if I were to ask for copies to be made here it might take some
time to get it done and I hate to keep your invaluable book very long.

Incidentally, were you aware that the lower ring of the book seems to have
been “sprung” so that it fails to shut closely and it is difficult to keep the pages in
proper place; furthermore there is danger of tearing the lower holes of the transparent
sheets. I am trying to be as careful of the book as I can.

In late April I hope to visit Dr. Pinto in Omaha, General Truby and Mrs.
Lazear in California. I shall ask each to tell me of Dr. Ames' services.

list.item:
12. In your letter to me (March 5, 1942 - page 2) you say that Dr. Ames
“was not only in charge of the (experimental) cases but he assisted in selection of the
men who submitted to the experimentation and he inoculated them.” I have never seen
that statement elsewhere. Can you prove it? Surely Drs. Reed or Carroll inoculated
the men at Camp Lazear.

13. You will be interested to know that Agramonte's “Inside History
of a Great Medical Discovery” was first published December, 1915 in “Scientific
American” and later privately reprinted by Agramonte himself in Havana. You can
look up the “Scientific American” in your local public library.

14. In addition to the material in your book do you have any snapshots
or photographs of Dr. Ames or his colleagues in Cuba in 1900-1901 at Camp Lazear,
Columbia Barracks or Military Hospital %1 or any Havana newspaper clippings about
the epidemic or experiments?

div1.p:
Whatever help you can give me I will greatly appreciate. I wish I had
known your address last year because I was invited to speak at a medical convention
in Atlanta and spent two very pleasant days there. I should indeed have liked to
meet you.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
